questions.question_text: Employees at a company report that they are unable to access the Internet. A network technician notices the workstations are receiving IP addresses that do not follow the IP addressing scheme of the corporate network. Upon further inspection, the technician finds an employee has plugged a rogue wireless router into the corporate network. Which of the following settings would have prevented this situation?

discussion.content: In computer networking, DHCP snooping is a series of techniques applied to improve the security of a DHCP infrastructure. DHCP servers allocate IP addresses to clients on a LAN. DHCP snooping can be configured on LAN switches to exclude rogue DHCP servers and remove malicious or malformed DHCP traffic. Wikipedia

DHCP snooping is a series of techniques applied to improve the security of a DHCP infrastructure. DHCP servers allocate IP addresses to clients on a LAN. DHCP snooping can be configured on LAN switches to exclude rogue DHCP servers and remove malicious or malformed DHCP traffic.

Although it sounds like a bad thing, DHCP snooping is just the opposite. It is the
capability for a switch to look at packets and drop DHCP traffic that it
determines to be unacceptable based on the defined rules. The purpose of this is
to prevent rogue DHCP servers from offering IP addresses to DHCP clients.

questions.question_text: Which of the following protocols operates at the data link layer of the OSI model?

discussion.content: Examples of data link protocols are Ethernet, Point-to-Point Protocol (PPP), HDLC and ADCCP. In the Internet Protocol Suite (TCP/IP), the data link layer functionality is contained within the link layer, the lowest layer of the descriptive model, which is assumed to be independent of physical infrastructure.
process of elimination on this one boys, rest are not even related

questions.question_text: Several open conference rooms have active wired network connections. To discourage unauthorized users, a network technician wants to require users in the conference rooms to authenticate to the network before gaining access. Which of the following would be the BEST network technology to use?

discussion.content: it's wired so wpa doesn't apply
802.1x is a standard not a technology. WPA AES/TKIP is an encryption or technology type both of which would require you to authenticate to the network. But your guess is as good as mine.
keyword: authenticate

questions.question_text: Which of the following ports should be open on a host-based firewall for a user who needs email and file-sharing capabilities? (Choose two.)

comments.content:
Port 21(FTP) -- File Transfer
Port 445(SMB) -- File share

discussion.content: Answers A and E are the most correct for this scenario. Port 21 is used for file-sharing and Port 587 (SMTP over SSL) is used for email client to email server communication.
Nowadays it is highly recommended to keep port 445 closed on firewalls. I think the reason why the answer is A and E, is because of the wording "should".
SMB seems more like "file sharing" than FTP.

445 is SMB file sharing.. so it is either A/E or D/E. Port 587 is the only email related port.. I don't think it is the Kerberos port. Hopefully the real CompTIA question is worded a little more precisely.

comments.content: a host-based firewall for a user who needs email and file-sharing capabilities? - E - 587 is secure smtp, the preferred email send port.

discussion.content:
I believe the answers are correct. The user needs file-sharing capabilities. FTP uses port 20,21. 
The user needs email capabilities. 587 is associated with SMTP. SMTP does not always have to be port 25. Can anyone verify?

https://www.serversmtp.com/port-587/

I think that correct answer is B and D.
88 Kerberos port, it is needed to authenticate in order to access the email server.
445 is SMB file sharing protocol port

Pretty sure this answer is incorrect.
It’s A and E, ftp(file sharing) and SMTP(email).
Port 88 is Kerberos

comments.content: it was asking for the whole network, not just the PCs. It'd be a single line from the router to the firewall to the switch so it's a bus. It's a goofy question, but Comptia is all about trickery

discussion.content: There is no way to infer how the network is connected. I'm 99% sure that this is a Star typology. Answer A.
Could someone explain why it wouldn't be a star topology? Maybe I'm confused over the wording of the question but if you have a switch why would you use a bus over a star topology?

comments.content: I think they meant you to think of it as the router, firewall, and switch connecting in a line, then after the switch, you have the PCs. It would still be more of a star. I don't get it.

discussion.content: Wouldn't automatically be a Star topology if a router is involved? Classically, in any Star topology diagram, a router was always the center of the star.

physically - its Bus topology 
Logically - it is Star topology
This question sounds very vague

I guess it star topology if you looking at it from PC side. But from Network side of it, it is a BUS topology. Ask your self, are you getting ready for A+ or a Network+.
Since you are studying for network plus, than you should be looking at the network side which is a BUS topology.
I taught A was the right answer but bus fit the best for this question.
The router, firewall, and switch are bus, but the PCs are star. Some of the questions are confusing.
This would technically be a hybrid topology since everything up to the switch would be a bus and everything after the switch would be a star so essentially creating a star-bus topology
The only way this could be a Bus topology is if there was a Hub being used instead of a switch. No Hub = no Bus. Answer is 100% Star topology. Thank you and have a good day.
I check the answer with Jason Dion. The correct answer is Bus.
I agree, I think it's start. If they said ONE pc connected to the switch, I would be onboard, but they said several. No way that's a bus
The Official CompTIA® Network+® Study Guide describes p64 the standard 3 layers corporate network as a star topology or a hierarchical star topology: the only correct answer is star

A daisy chain is formed from the router to the firewall to the switch, creating a bus topology. Also, the switch is the central device connecting several computers, creating a star topology. I would say its a star-bus topology or a hybrid topology. This is another weird question.

There is no way this is a bus topology. It's a star topology. Any network requires a router, firewall(preferably) and at least one switch. So if this answer is bus topology then it would mean that ALL networks are bus topology.

In an Ethernet bus topology, a single connection failure brings down the entire network. If you lose connection from one workstation to switch, everything else still operates. If router, firewall and switch are connected in-line, you have combination of star topology and bus topology (assuming direct connection between router and firewall) which makes it hybrid. I don't think anyone uses token ring or bus ethernet in this day and age so why bother asking!
Star topology

The correct answer is A. Star.
https://networksmania.wordpress.com/topics/network-topology/star-topology/
Rememer that one characteristic of star topology is that it has 1 point-of-failure, bus has multiple. Also there is no centralized device, by using the elimination method, the one that's left is D
Physical Star, Logical Bus.. The Answer is A
Sheesh, people. It's a star. You can't have a switch with multiple computers in a bus. I mean... really now.

I think the question is asking about the overall network topology, router, firewall, and switch are in a line creating a bus. yes the switch topology is a star but I think that part is to just throw you off.

comments.content: Yup, review Mike Myers chapter 2 about physical network. Star is just with the device in the middle, but the firewall/router/switch lineup makes it a BUS.

I agree with you guys, the fact that we have a router, firewall and a switch just sounds like a bus to me. I believe the multiple PCs description is just to throw us off and trick us like CompTIA does!

A switch in this situation is generally going to be connected out to other devices though.. and we are talking about "physical" layout of the network, which is a bunch of PCs connected to a switch.. sure the switch is connected to other stuff, but that's normal. Star I say.

discussion.content: I would think it would be bus since all the nodes would be connected to a single cable or a "backbone"
To me looks like star is the correct answer. As long as the PCs connection connects to a centralized station, switch/router, than it would consider a start.

questions.question_text: A network technician has created a network that consists of a router, a firewall, a switch, and several PCs. Which of the following physical network topologies was created?
